comment_text: Question for you, Tim! Why do Falcon 9 boosters have that pattern of black soot on them after reentry? It seems to be strangely unequal, very dark at the bottom and then suddenly white again, with some more tint towards the top. I figure it has something to do with the different burns for reentry and for landing but I haven’t been able to think of a clear explanation. Thanks!
who are those 2 dudes? and why are they in your shot?

My idea for retrieving the fairings is to design an aircraft or multiple aircraft with a tailhook or net that will go up in the air and catch the fairings in the air to slow their speed down. You would need a tip with a magnetic end and some part of the fairing with enough metal for the tip to catch it. Sort of like how a carrier catches a plane out at sea. You just need a crazy American pilot to figure out the recovery procedures for you.

You might even be able to use a Hot air balloon with a tether line.

I think my idea for a tailhook would bebest because you wouldn't have to add weight to the initial fairing designs.

comment_text: Did you use a long telephoto lens and the camera far behind to make this result?

Looking forward to your review of the events. Although SpaceX and the official tracking cameras do show great shots of the launches, I find amateur footage even more interesting. In fact, the "home made" footage always seems to have much better sound - and you get a much better impression of what it must really have been like to watch the launch in person.
You can be seen in the wide shots just to the left of the clock! https://youtu.be/I7LJIuB2CHE
